conclusion: The square OABC has side length R because AC is a quarter-circle of radius R.
The arc AC is a 90° (π/2-radian) portion of a circle of radius R centered at O.
Refractive index of the transparent material is n = 2.
Light is emitted isotropically from O and first strikes the curved surface AC from the interior.
At the curved surface, Snell’s law applies: n sin θi = n₀ sin θt, where n₀ = 1 (air) and θi is the incident angle with respect to the normal inside the material.
Total internal reflection (TIR) occurs if sin θt would exceed 1, i.e., if sin θi > 1/n = 1/2. Hence the critical angle inside the material is θc = arcsin(1/2) = 30°.
A ray emitted from O towards a point P on AC makes an angle φ with OA (measured along the arc).
At P, the incident angle relative to the local normal equals φ.
Rays for which φ < θc (i.e., φ < 30°) refract out; rays for which φ > 30° are totally internally reflected.

Among the refracted rays (φ < 30°), only some reach AB or BC directly. Rays striking the portion of the arc between φ = 0 and φ = 15° refract and then intersect AB or BC without further internal reflection, whereas rays with 15° ≤ φ < 30° refract but miss both faces and remain trapped.
There are two 'forbidden' angular zones on the arc: a) 30° ≤ φ ≤ 90° (TIR) b) 15° ≤ φ < 30° (refracts but still cannot exit).
Combine the two angular intervals: 15° ≤ φ ≤ 90°.
The length of an arc of a circle of radius R subtending angle Δφ is L = R Δφ.
The length of the portion of arc AC on which rays from O cannot exit directly through AB or BC is L = (5π/12) R.
